content: <xml>   <records>        <record>       <contributors>         <authors>           <author>Frank, Mario</author>           <author>Schmolling, Jakob</author>           <author>Zipser, Florian</author>         </authors>       </contributors>       <titles>         <title>Merging data, the essence of creation of multi-layer corpora</title>         <secondary-title/>       </titles>       <doi>10.5281/zenodo.15640</doi>       <pages/>       <volume/>       <number/>       <keywords>         <keyword>Pepper</keyword>         <keyword>Salt</keyword>         <keyword>ANNIS</keyword>         <keyword>converter</keyword>         <keyword>conversion framework</keyword>         <keyword>linguistics</keyword>         <keyword>linguistic data</keyword>         <keyword>linguistic format</keyword>         <keyword>merging</keyword>         <keyword>corpora</keyword>         <keyword>multi-layer corpus</keyword>       </keywords>       <dates>         <year>2014</year>         <pub-dates>           <date>2014-03-06</date>         </pub-dates>       </dates>       <abstract><p>The last couple of years have shown an increasing number of multi layer corpora. Such<br />     corpora allow the analysis of phenomena spreading through multiple annotation layers, for<br />     example corpora like TueBaDZ (see: http://www.sfs.uni-tuebingen.de/ascl/ressourcen/corpora/tueba-dz.html), PCC (see: http://www.ling.uni-potsdam.de/acl-lab/Forsch/pcc/pcc.html), FALKO (see: https://u.hu-berlin.de/falko) and many other corpora contain annotations on syntactical, rhetorical, information structural and other layers. Often, annotations were created manually, or semi-automatically with different tools like EXMARaLDA (see: http://www.exmaralda.org/), TreeTagger (see: http://www.cis.uni-muenchen.de/~schmid/tools/TreeTagger/) and MMAX2 (see: http://mmax2.sourceforge.net/).<br />     These tools are powerful and usable but unfortunately only provide a minimum of<br />     interoperability, which impedes the creation of multi layer corpora. Thus, multiple layers of<br />     such corpora often had to be merged by hand or by very proprietary scripts implemented for<br />     just one use case and therefore could not be reused for other corpora easily.<br />     With this poster we present a tool which merges several layers of annotations into a single<br />     multi layer corpus. When creating a multi layer corpus, several analyses base on the same<br />     primary data and often also on the same tokenization.<br />     We started merging the data on the tokenization level and traversed bottom up, to merge even<br />     higher levels of annotation. This concept is implemented in a module for the converter<br />     framework Pepper (see: https://u.hu-berlin.de/saltnpepper) with use of the common meta-<br />     model Salt. By using Pepper, the merging module is able to handle all formats which can be<br />     imported by a Pepper module. Multi layered corpora then can be mapped into a multilayer<br />     formats like PAULA (Chiarcos et al. 2008), GrAF (Ide &amp; Suderman 2007) or can be imported<br />     into ANNIS.</p></abstract>     </record>      </records> </xml>
